nA7dY55LFuQUESDptJZ1NA.text: My husband and I came here in March 2017 for dinner one night during our time in London. We had reservations (which were relatively easy to secure) and arrived to our table. The restaurant is packed and busy on a weeknight. We ordered:1) Ribeye steak - my husband ordered this and was underwhelmed. maybe his expectations were too high but he said it was only OK2) duck confit - I really enjoyed this dish and felt the flavors were tasty and just right.3) onion soup - my husband ordered this too and again, he thought it was just "eh".Overall, the service was friendly although they were so busy that it didn't feel as welcoming. Even though this place has high marks, we left feeling like the experience was only mediocre.

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Ribeye steak & frites, duck confit, onion soup

-sE3EVSGSNR2Ir5fv2doHA.text: The food was good, not great...but we finished our plates ;-)The service by our main waiter was good, but was overwhelmed by training a new assistant/ busboy...who was in waaaay over his head. That made the wait for our dishes to be cleared as long it takes to walk Covent Garden and back... we feel sorry for anyone's first day on the job, but between hearing the manager berate the waiter, the waiter berate the busboy, and the busboy sinking hopelessly, we were all to exhausted to enjoy the meal. To bad, different circumstances, I'm sure it would've been much better for this quaint and well appointed French restaurant. Only a 1 Star minus. Give it a try!

_F9gPyJ-Ger239RqaB7UTw.text: Nice decor, friendly service.The tables are too close together. I felt I could have easily joined the conversations next to us.I had the chopped salad. It was very good. There were more toppings then actual lettuce which was weird but I enjoyed it. My fiancé had the full breakfast. Great portion size and good food.

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Chopped salad
Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Full breakfast

9-6sPUIsokeTOkQgTnS4iQ.text: The short: you can expect a solid meal and great service at Balthazar. The longer: I came for a weekday breakfast business meeting, and was greeted by a kind hostess who coat checked my coat and umbrella. We had a round booth table, the restaurant was beautifully decorated with tons of staff. Our waiter immediately got us water, coffee and iced tea. I ordered poached eggs with smoked salmon. The homemade English muffin was delicious, the salmon was fresh, and the eggs were perfectly cooked. I was able to get the hollandaise sauce on the side. Overall, great meal, excellent service in a prime location.

975zc-7GEqfYsTsMRcIEiQ.text: I love the NYC location so I had to try this one while I was in London recently. It did not disappoint. I had the chicken Paillard followed by profiteroles for dessert. Everything was excellent and the service was great too. As soon as I sat down the waiter asked if I wanted a glass of wine and he gave it to me on the house! The restaurant itself is in a nice area and the inside looks just like the New York location. It also wasn't overly expensive which I appreciated since I was on a business trip. Remains one of my favorites!!

Jm6NPbGoXkhofeZvQOhvQg.text: These guys saved me from the ineptitude of the corner bakery, just down the block, who couldn't seem to handle 2 customers at once.  Being familiar with the patisserie and restaurant in NYC, I knew I could find quality and service here.They came through with my Americano, and small almond loaf, that was just enough to take the edge off my jet-lagged feed cycle, before lunch.  Two pleasant young ladies waited on me, and chatted with locals.  It wasn't crowded in the 5 stool interior, and it was just a nice and relaxing respite.

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Nice Americano and small almond loaf. Nice respite on a stool.

JGMsWozuJkZVLmYubNlZBA.text: We visited this French Brasserie after seeing Mama Mia.  Very vibrant atmoshere and the food is stellar!  Cool vibe, amazing food, and open late. Perfect for after show or just late night bite to eat!

QIzNL_oykAqq1gAOFfe12w.text: I passed by a week ago and find out they do a good deal of prix menu and promised will treat myself for that. Glad that i booked the restaurant to secure our table for lunch. When i walked in...the interior look so grant with high ceiling with hanging fans.The prix fixe menu is simple and has a good selections and inexpensive. We has three courses only cost £22.50. Lovely Starter including soup of the the day, squid ink risotto..and i love the main course..roasted pollock..thick cod with peas. Desserts of the day look creative..it has peach with creamy white chocolate shell. The meal taste good and we really enjoy it.

fg_hgXkQq00IFPQn9uEHPg.text: What a wonderful evening -- I owe virtually all of it to the wonderful barman who attended to me. The check says "sam p" was serving, so I'm going to say it was sam. First, he made an absolutely impeccable martini, and even paused to inquire about my preferred dryness. It was wonderful. I noted the wonderful lemon presence, and he cut a fresh lemon peel and squeezed it over the back of my hand to show me the freshness of lemon oils and the difference they make. Then, when I expressed an interest in the vermouth he used, he very enthusiastically shared their house blend (cocchio + standard dry). I mentioned I'd never heard of cocchio, and what followed was a tour de force of making a guest feel special -- he personally walked me through the different kinds of vermouth cocchio makes, their characteristics, their history, their relationship to other aperitifs like Lillet -- and then he gave me a taste of each. I mean, not only did I have a great time, enjoy a spectacular martini (and a perfect rare steak frites), but I actually learned something that I can bring home with me. I will consider my next trip to London incomplete without a visit to Balthazar for a drink with Sam. Sam, you are a gentleman and a scholar. Thanks for a great evening!

G7lWQE0fP6589uT-xVyUxA.text: Classic brunch food with a lovely atmosphere. Good portion sizes and if you get the bread basket they give you four different types of jams/spreads for the bread!

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom

FPObqb1SbYa80XTncHNDdw.text: Still good after a few years, but maybe showing its age a bit. We managed to walk in without a reservation, at around 8 pm on a Monday. We've eaten here before, as well as  dining at the original NYC location, and have always had a nice time and decent food. The scallops were a fine starter, and the onion soup was classic. Both Lamb and steak frites were tasty if perhaps unmemorable. Service is fine but can get a bit thin if the place fills up. We prefer to sit at the banquette tables overlooking all the action ( there wasn't much this visit ), though the padded seat is getting a bit lumpy. Many diners prefer the closer together tables in the middle of the classic bistro space. We have spotted the occasional celebrity here but most diners are having pre and post theatre dinners. Great Covent Garden location.

Z-DQiTFmarLqFdsDhzdaqQ.text: Sadly this was a let down and isn't a patch on the NYC one. I suspect the location in London is one of the issues as it ends up being full of tourists and almost feels like an Angus Steak House!Our waiter knew diddly about the menu and when i asked for a standard drink - fresh lime and soda, he got a proper sweat on and then told me they didn't stock that cocktail?! The actual brunch was so so but nothing special.

K8gJnmQ0_llV9PBQ8BkeZw.text: Yum! Had read negative professional reviews in the papers and was hesitant to try it, but so glad I took the plunge.Pros: Lovely ambiance (similar to Delaunay), excellent front of house staff, excellent waitstaff. Asked to have table changed during a busy lunch hour as wanted more privacy for a lunch meeting and was accommodated immediately and gracefully. Plats du jour are an excellent deal. Food is consistent, menu is varied, pricing very reasonable for quality of food. Balthazar house salad had just the perfect touch of truffle oil and seasonal ingredients. Mains are superb. Even the bread basket offers a step up from the standard dry baguette that one finds elsewhere. And the takeaway bakery next door is charming.Cons: Forced to come up with something, simply that there can be a bit of wait it seems others have discovered this gem as well!

WwxJwYTWJmInMn-JFmSmnQ.text: Done the NY one. Enjoyed the buzz. So when it opened here in London we thought we should give it a try.But getting in at a reasonable time is a different matter. All booked up.Just so happens we had tickets for Charlie and the chocolate factory at Drury Lane on Thursday. 7.30 kick off. Balthazar right outside. Why not try a pre-theatre raid.A 6pm table of 3 was duly booked. We got there on time and the place was already busy. The bar was full and three quarters of the tales were taken. Bags were swiftly taken and we were at our table.Balthazar London feels exactly the same as New York. Loud. Thronging. hot. Nicely decked out in authentic French brasserie tiling and furniture. Serving staff whizz round all over the gaff and there is a big seafood bar at the back to whet the appetite. This is proper tourist London stuff, and I don't mean that in a bad way. Slap bang in the middle of covent garden and full of hip things out for a good time. It feels great.The menu is what you'd expect from a good French brasserie. Nice bread arrived to munch on, plenty of it. Followed by a good moules et frites which was lifted by the inclusion of caramelised fennel. The boy had macaroni cheese sans the bacon and the missus had a skirt steak that was full of taste. My chip were a little soggy was my only complaint on the food. But it was pretty expensive for what we got I thought.However, you're paying for the great atmosphere, not the food. And for a bit of a treat if you're painting good old London Town red, it's definitely got it. Go there and show out. It's fun. Not perfect food and a bit pricey but great fun nonetheless. Not quite a 4 but a high 3 stars well earned.Nb If I did theatre reviews I Would give Charlie and the chocolate factory 6 stars. It was truly brilliant. And I hate the theatre.  Book it. And try Balthazar before for a proper night out!The place was heaving by the time we left at 7. So do book.

lijXzvp_N3hTOUpuZ8d2SA.text: Popped into the small takeaway section next door to the main restaurant, greeted promptly by the very friendly staff, purchased a selection of fresh bread (you can ask for half a loaf if you require) this time I got a spelt, white and an olive ciabatta. The olive ciabatta is one if the tastiest I've ever had, loads of flavour and full of olives! Good selection of fresh sandwiches and small cakes to tempt you.Located very close to the piazza.

Z3QRMIKTODne-l7ENuFs5A.text: Well priced for what you get. Superbly cooked sharing steaks and sparkling service from our supremely rude (in a naughty way!) French waiter who's grasp of innuendo was second to none. Desserts were also pretty good and was overjoyed that they resisted the urge to put a f***ing raspberry or dome such in the bottom of their creme brûlée (a pet hate of mine and all too common these days)

X2jlorjlpqQnNwLAjw1kRQ.text: A Near exact replica of the famous SoHo location in NYC, i have to love this spot as it reminds me of home. With classics like moules frites, steak tar tar, the seafood platter and excellent bloody marys, this is the perfect brunch spot for any event.

HYjvqocF8yIze-a9lvX0TA.text: The bar is very impressive.  This is the sort of place the word über was invented for.  The wine list is great, the bar menu is great, it isn't cheap and doesn't feel it.  I was only here for drinks and snacks.  If you're in Covent Garden and haven't decided on where to go this wouldn't be a bad place to start.

hSTxhOsZRD2kC1FWZ0U5Bw.text: Impressive dining room,  nice for a special treat. I've been for breakfast twice now and had the avocado on toast with poached egg. Lovely. They have a private dining room now for larger groups.

0cTLXcykIGwBVKWn7GlAhQ.text: Thank you for our lovely meal, pre and post opera. Food delicious, service excellent. Staff very knowledgeable and kind. Thank you.

YO9OQAsxZFmPSHkLsEErcw.text: On a recent trip, went to Balthazar with a friend who had great food at Balthazar in the past. Possibly this was the one-off day but the food was very average. We both essentially got a steak and it wasn't great. The wine though was brilliant - we got recommendation from the sommelier and it was a great suggestion. Will visit again though since it possibly was just a busy Friday eve.

-UwSFoSfzaqjeUwaQlFKPA.text: I had to wait for my friend so I spent about 45 minutes in the bar area. I love the bar! Great selection of wines and friendly bartenders. Food was excellent. I had the beetroot dish for a starter, the salmon with spinach and lentils for my main, and chocolate for dessert. Service was excellent. I actually felt like I was in New York in this restaurant, they've definitely captured the NYC buzz.

ALQLO4ZzaJ-CFJXjdsJRUA.text: Spent an enjoyable afternoon over a classy bottle of beautiful tasting wine and a bowl of mussels and fries cooked to perfection, what more do you want in life. The ambience is great, the staff are attentive and understand how to look after the customers. Great place, priced accordingly but worth it.

WVoVHZR1IcjxVnxcvDH1Zg.text: Went here last night with 3 friends, good atmosphere although very noisy (we were in a nice semi-circular booth but I could hardly hear my friend across from me). Started with a cocktail, nice but at £10.50 a little steep for a small glass with a lot of ice. Food was tasty, I had fish pie which was rich but delicious, packed with fish, then the lemon posset for dessert, which was fine but nothing special.  Overall I came away with a bill for £50 (including a glass of wine) and felt that for the quality of the meal (and the wine), although good, it was a little overpriced. I had been expecting more because of the hype. Service was excellent. I probably wouldn't go again, too many amazing choices in London!

uroJ1gveQBF2p2xaQu_LkQ.text: Ambiance: perfect, busy, cute French bistro restaurant!Service: friendly, helpful, and a little slow. ( which you should expect from the French, they like to take their time)Food: perfect menu. Lobster, cooked perfectly, oysters, nice selection shucked just right, French onion was ok, nothing to ride hoe about. Reason for a 4: Balthazar in NY is better. They have a better selection of seafood. In NY, you can order jumbo prawns that are a true jumbo.  Also the baked bread in NY is fresher.  I still enjoyed the London restaurant and would highly recommend it.

xtn5U6M81i1gjhDijzQE3Q.text: Nice ambiance, great service, but definitely overpriced. Ordered the spaghetti with lobster--expected the meal to be a lot tastier. Overall, a good experience; I'd go back to try something new.

sCyYq-Wq9SzNha73dldyJg.text: Great bakery (haven't tried the restaurant). One of my fav stops in Covent Garden. Try the delicious spinach and mushroom croissant. Lovely presentation too.Super friendly staff and classic European (French) look. The classical music soundtrack is a bit old-fashioned but frankly better than some of the pretentious affect-pop one might hear in the more hipster coffee shops.A place that makes one feel good. If prices were a little lower, I'd give 5 stars (but they're within the norm).

kTrXeOqhd9GsQXmpCtPnmg.text: A "New York" brunch never quite had the perfect venue in London. There were a number of places that came close: Breakfast Club, Automat, Tom's Kitchen all came close in my books... but none ever truly captured the essence and food (read: pancakes) of those Saturday and Sunday mornings that I used to spend in Manhattan. Balthazar, which looks and feels identical to her sibling across the Atlantic, fits this niche perfectly. The food is well executed (the Huevos Rancheros were delicious during my visit this weekend), the staff attentive, the room well decorated, the sound level loud without being deafening. Balthazar is a place I could see myself returning to for dinner, for a drink... and certainly for another weekend brunch with friends.

vB6N3_LqdQBGHzsVY5EIWg.text: Came here for breakfast. Familiar with Balthazar from New York and was eager to try a traditional full English breakfast. it was yummy and didn't disappoint. My husband got some selection of pastries and jams. Carb overload but he enjoyed it. Overall, it was as expected: good food, a little pricey, and a little crowded. Not sure if I would even consider returning here for dinner as it seems to get booked up and there are tons of amazing places to have dinner in London (*cough cough Great Queen Street *cough cough*).

TZEUMZs0RV3_4VkUFT9hLQ.text: We booked Balthazar for a pre-theatre supper on my birthday. First impressions were great as we arrived early to have drinks at the busy bar. It had a buzzy atmosphere at 5pm and we ordered drinks whilst we waited for our table. I had an Aperol spritz which was watery and rather expensive for 9.50 but we perused the menu which sounded good and got shown to a nice corner table. This is where it all started to unravel. The wine list is ludicrously expensive and we ordered two half bottles as the house wines did not appeal. I ordered saffron risotto to start which had 1.1/2 (!) scallops on the top. It arrived with a skin on it so had either been sat waiting to be served or had been microwaved to high heaven. My boyfriend's game pate was not pate, more like a thick over seasoned terrine. Bread was a little stale and butter ice cold. My main was 1/2 a lobster which arrived served on a bed of ice with no fork or cracker to open it. Every time I tried to get some flesh out it was submerged in a slushy, icy bath and it felt like I got an 1/8 of a lobster! Pretty revolting and served with what appeared to be Heinz seafood sauce. My boyfriend's duck shepherd's pie was greasy, small and swimming in fat. All in all the bill came to £160 which we certainly anticipated, but for this price range you would expect high quality French food. We will not be returning, considering brasserie Zedel is not too far away and has a far more spectacular ambience for half the price I cannot believe Balthazar gets away with the terrible expensive food it has to offer. Please save your money and go elsewhere! London has so much more to offer than this overpriced mediocrity!

QV-uY4lQWtJ0gaYXhJjhZw.text: Very attentive staff made our first visit to Balthazar easily enjoyable. We didn't have a reservation but were promptly seated. Girlfriend had the eggs royale, I had the eggs hussard both of which were absolutely delicious. Afterwards we shared the waffles which were a bit dry and didn't come with enough berry sauce to make a difference. Staff very helpful again though and brought a generous serving of chocolate sauce on the side. Menu a bit boring but exactly what you would expect from a bistro brunch. Great service. Most food excellent. Highly recommended.

zTYsGD9AhVoYUYKTZShA7g.text: Came in on a Monday evening 7pm with 3 other girlfriends without a reservation. We were seated promptly without a wait-- we're off to a great start! Our waiter was knowledgable about the specials and was helpful without being too pushy. The restaurant itself is grand. High ceilings, chandeliers, wine bottles were lined up on the wall of the bar, and a plethora of fresh oysters and shrimp were displayed on ice. I started off with a chicken liver/foie gras appetizer. Very generous portions and tasty. For the main, I ordered the grilled dover sole and it was perfectly cooked! My friends ordered the lobster spaghetti, salmon, and steak frites and they all enjoyed their dishes as well. If I wasn't a broke college student, I would have ordered the chocolate souffle for dessert-- it sounded divine!Balthazar is a great place to people watch and treat yourself. The ambience is ornate, the service is wonderful and prompt. A little pricy, but I'd definitely come back!

AXMoWenT3N3R2skbTRdNsg.text: *Bolsheviks beware, seriously bourgeois review is brewing along with the coffee*______________Sometimes I just love being bourgeois.Frothy coffee and pricey pastries quelquefois, really is the only way to start the day, darling.If, like myself you were sheepishly excited at the expansion of Keith McNally's faux-Français New York establishment into exciting new territory (London), yet were NOT terribly thrilled about the prospect of hitting redial on the phone every minute for three days in vain expectation of securing a dining reservation (I mean I have so many better things to do with my precious bourgeois time, right) the Balthazar Bakery located right next the the restaurant proper may be a nice solution for a coy little indulgence - experience the atmosphere sans the wait.Having lived a block away from the original restaurant-bakery duet in Soho NYC (I know, how bourgeois), I was of course excited to relive my (occasional) self-spoiling mornings and thus decided to breakfast à la Balthazar aujourd'hui. I was not disappointed. In fact, I was exuberantly delighted to sample their twist on a classic croque monsieur [soused in béchamel-sauce finished with Lea-and-Perrins lacerations]- the textural experience was sumptuously akin to that initial and rather glorious creme-caramel fracturing moment. I'm afraid biting through the crispy, grilled bread surface into the soft layering of jambon et fromage interior, is simply worth the excessive £4.50 it demands.Bien sûr, the usual boulangerie window-pageant of baked goods is certainly inviting, and the gleaming white-tiled walls bedecked with cursive 'B'-inscribed wholemeal loaves exude a constructed charm one only thought possible in a Hollywood studio (you have ACTUALLY been to Paris, yah). Though I would even be so bold as to suggest that the B-B London even trumps its NYC predecessor in terms of the open space and ability to convince its patrons that they are actually there to shop (market-style) rather than just queuing for a costly caffeine and butter-filled petit déjeuner, distributed in a somewhat nonchalant and brusque manner (although that would probably be the most authentically French thing about it).Bon appetit, comrades.

hY5iVbSwgwNsnHspdW4J_A.text: Had the Chopped Salad along with onion rings, my other guests had the Salad Nicoise and the giant Mac and Cheese. The Mac and Cheese was particularly awesome. Great way to transition back from great French vacation food to good US fare...

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom

ooS5wIef77TX-ee1Zsd6tw.text: The plan was to come here for a late Saturday Brunch and get some eggs. We arrived to find a queue but had looking booked, so we went straight through. After we walked in and were seated I managed to glimpse so amazing dishes which made me think twice about the original plan. I ended up going for the burger. Cooked to preference, with a great homemade sauce and bun. It also came swimming in a sea of French fries. Normally I wouldn't complain but maybe it was a bit too much as I don't like to waste food. My partner stuck to the original plan and got a cheese omelette. I tried this also but it was overly cheese and quite small. Coffee was also top notch. Staff were very friendly, attentive when needed but let you get on with your meal in peace. (Visit - 09/05/2015 Lunch)

zG9Uygf_ebsEvPtEmYMeQg.text: We had such a positive experience here, I can't wait to take the rest of our family back. My daughter and I were shopping in Covent Garden and we stopped for lunch at the bar.  I had a delicious chopped salad and the manager and bartender were so kind to chat with us and make a special crepe for my daughter who was hoping for the pancakes.  I lived in NYC for 7 years and used to love going to Balthazar.  This one is equally as great--fabulous atmosphere, staff and food--a few of the people at the bar were clearly regulars and it felt like Cheers--where everybody knows your name.

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Lobster spaghetti
Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Artichoke gnocchi
Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Children's moules frites

zGK3UlRmYuvmUC9dRE0E8A.text: Happy dance for one of my favorite NYC staples making its way to London!For the entire three years that I've been living in London, I've been hearing rumblings of the prodigal son, Keith McNally bringing his French brasserie juggernaut across the Atlantic. And with much fanfare and panache, the will-he-won't-he speculation finally ended last Monday evening. They're currently only open for dinner service, but brunch and lunch service is coming soon. After 137 tries (thanks, iPhone for keeping track) to get through the booking line last Friday morning, my fortitude was rewarded with an opening week dinner spot. So, last night we sat down for an early-ish dinner, that is very much what I remember from back home. The staff is an eclectic mix of London's restaurant service elite; NYC Balthazar linchpins; and an eclectic mix of French servers representing the best of The Hexagon's diverse regions. It's an impressive bunch! The American hospitality smacks you in the face as soon as you walk through the door. At first blush, it can be a bit much for those of us used to the cold shoulder presented at so many London establishments. But we acclimated almost immediately--it sort of made me miss home. Sigh.Water appeared via busboy -- what!?. Our Breton waiter brought us expertly made cocktails (Brian and Tom were both poached from other top London cocktail establishments). Fine de Claires on-the-half-shell were ordered and brought in a flash. Briny and fresh, I was in heaven. Bread from their boulangerie next door was devoured with French butter (of course). I started with the onion soup, which was unctuous and just a little bit sweet. The hubs had a small portion of the beef tartare, which he figures is some of the best he's ever eaten--and he eats it a lot. Another member of the waitstaff recommended a bottle of red from the Jura, her home turf, that was one of the more interesting bottles of wine I've ever had. Slightly effervescent and light in color, it takes a couple of sips to fall in love, but amazing once you get there.It accompanied the whole chicken for two very well. The chicken itself was roasted to perfection and served with jus, a mix of veg, and velvety potato puree. By this point we were stuffed to the gills, but dessert was needed--for research purposes obviously. I ordered the tart du jour, lemon with a raspberry reduction. Lemon tart is my Achilles heel as of late, and this one was very good. Although, it was more of a lemon mousse with crust, than a lemon tart. Even so, still delicious! My partner in crime had the cheesecake. It was a small portion, but it was so rich, there was no reason for more than they served. He nearly licked the plate clean. My only complaint at this point is the timing is a bit off. The coffee came before we had finished our dessert, and after presenting us with the whole chicken, it went back into the kitchen for plating for what seemed like an eternity; I think it was actually more like 15 minutes in human time. But it's their first week, so I imagine things will get smoother with time. For those of you who've fallen for the New York Balthazar, you'll recognize the room as an almost exact replica. Other brilliant American aspects include walk-in seating at the bar, the seafood tower, and a true New Yawka working the door. Did I mention the busboys? Oh, and how could I forget? It's reasonably priced; I mean, for Central London anyway.Yes, as my husband said, it seems like the universe is finally throwing us a bone on the London dining scene. I think a standing weekend reservation may be in order.

HlBLl1kV0UbjJYyUaGuDRw.text: Everyone was talking about it so I decided to check it out for lunch. I must say I have never been to the NYC one.The decor is respecting what the americans probably think it is (or was?) a french posh restaurant, a  bit "ville lumiere" with a lot of big mirrors and lamps.the food is good and the service is good and polite. My dad and I had a big steak with french fries, while my mum had an omelette. We were satisfied. I kinda like the place, probably will come back since I have heard that the brunch is very good.

esEJWW7cWIAQXAYTc1wOgA.text: As far as brunch spots go I'd say this place is a safe bet. The service was good and the food was tasty. The eggs Benedict was good but didn't come with a side so I was left hungry. A half order of the NY pancakes finished me off and rounded out the meal. The meal was expensive relative to what you get. That could be a function of the location being next to covent garden square (great place to grab a cup of coffee and listen to the street performers. Exactly what I'm doing as I write this review) or London being expensive...full stop.

d-b3DB2XYbWrt0pzMeklOw.text: In a word, the breakfast I had here was incredibly underwhelming, and the other people in my party said the exact same thing.  The service was not bad by any means, but the servers did come off as a little bit scattered.  My waffles were quite dry on their own, and the fact that they gave me no syrup with them really did not help.  One person in my party ordered scrambled eggs, and they were essentially in liquid form.  It was actually quite disgusting, even to look at, let alone eat it.  I know that this place has a good reputation, especially the NYC location, so I was disappointed by the experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. waffles, dry and underwhelming

8069NIwJxh3M7rG2W5-55g.text: As many of my fellow Yelpers have said, it's the perfect Americanized French brasserie brunch spot.  Very NYC in Londontown.  Very good service, very good eggs, very good champagne.  Amazing soufflé, worth it if it's just for that alone!  It was the perfect way to celebrate my birthday before catching the matinee performance of The Book of Mormon.

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Birthday souffle!

OgKJl2LqxMn8AH-P-tMZRQ.text: The American influx of Central London eateries continues! My mate had to book weeks in advance to scoop a Friday night reservation and the place was buzzing. Uber prime location with cool interior that lets you pretend you're in NYC (or at least that Sex and the City ep it appears in!). Very much a place to see and be seen with a price tag to match; the food is just 'ok'. Service is top notch though and left me with a smile on my face, even after a disappointingly squishy chocolate soufflé.

JVVaLHCZPB429K14hUX29w.text: Setting: This restaurant is big and airy and it really feels like you could be in a mid-20th century French brasserie. The atmosphere is very relaxed and is great for brunch. Even the bathrooms are big and bright. Being in Covent Gardens this is a great location to meet someone from the other side of the city for brunch.Service: The service was excellent. The staff were attentive, friendly and helpful without ever being overbearing. I really enjoyed this aspect of the experience.Food: I had my first ever Escargot here and despite my hesitancy over eating snails they were delicious. As brunch goes I wold recommend the Moules Frites. The mussel portions are very generous (I was full before I got to the fries). However the fries are more crunch than substance and a thicker cut (if going off the french fry vibe a little) would make them even better. I definitely want to try the rest of the menu and would come back.

SXvLDa-ZNlRR5s2-TQ1bZA.text: It was really just ok....and I cannot understand the hype of this establishment other than the fact it's from New York and therefore that MUST mean we should all love it for the ''New York chicness'' or whatever.......The decor was very French bistro, the lighting all soft and yellow toned so you felt as though you walked right into an instagram photoshot. I'm sure it would be a very ''chic'' place, there is no other word but chic for this place, to hang out for brunch on Sundays. But I was not impressed with the food selection nor the quality of the seafood. The chairs also had no cushions on them so you were sat in this hard wooden chair for the entire evening which makes your bum sore and your skirt sticking to the back of your legs. The tables were tiny and they tried to squeeze as much cutlery, bread plates, bread baskets, glasses and what have you, on this tiny (again hard topped) table. There were also A LOT of tables crammed into the whole place, as if the proprietors were trying to simulate a cosy, vintage style, café atmosphere....but actually, to me, did nothing more than to increase the noise levels and made everthing appear very messy.....Verdict - dislike!

yWP7Y3GWSDipE-Tu-7uKag.text: visited Balthazar London after a number of visit at Balthazar New-York - same menu, different currency! food was excellent, as expected, although in London they have quirky hours . Seemed that the pricing was significantly higher than NYC - Why?

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. The place. Such a place !!!

9PLrgTrV3-gEYVMarqUEVQ.text: Visited this bakery a couple of times now for lunch. They do really tasty sarnies, and normally I'm not a huge sandwich fan. The bread they use is really good and the fillings are quite interesting - I've tried the roast beef and celeriac slaw in a focaccia and the ham and butter baguette - it has hidden tiny gherkins! Yum! They sell salad boxes and lots of different yummy looking cakes (unfortnately haven't sampled any yet).The bakery has a couple of counter style seats inside but not many. The place is quite pricey for a bakery but I would say worth it if you need a lunch time treat to brighten your day!

g05Qz7kNetkYBaQmSces3Q.text: Came here last night. This is a lovely traditional looking French restaurant with American features. I was bewitched by the interior and by the very good service. They put a rush on for us when we let them know we had a show to get to, but it didn't affect the quality. I had the garlic prawns to start with the most delicious olive bread. The sauce was rich with the aroma of prawn and fish; very moreish! I then moved on to the steak frites but I found the sirloin a bit tough. I had someone else's fillet and that was perfectly seasoned and tender. Don't go for the house sparkling white unless you prefer it less brut. The champagne was much better. We also had a Pinot noir which was excellent. I had a brilliant evening in this vibrant and buzzy restaurant. Truly I can't wait to go back!

htvb9PSg8625RnOYGkKAgQ.text: I come here for brunch at the weekends or for lunch when I'm not feeling well. Sometimes when I dine alone I receive a complementary glass of sparkling wine, which definitely helps me to feel better. The brunch pancakes are superbly well balanced with fruit, syrup, and creme freche. And for lunch my favourite is to have the skate wing, which is cooked just like my Mum used to. Whatever I have I find the flavour combinations to be perfectly balanced. Unfortunately the price is a little higher than I would like so I don't come as often as I want.

7NdPziFowKv8WBzIpWZXXw.text: Been going to the New York one since the the 90s, never had a bad experience, the one in London is a copy of the NY one intern of atmosphere, service quality, and quality of dishes.. Few dishes are different in the menu in London.  Very good wine list reasonably priced.

photos.caption: Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. Lobster spaghetti was superb
Photo of Balthazar - London, United Kingdom. To die for

p7CXWwXlpb1FJp_liic5GQ.text: Well get that dialing finger at the ready because you're going to need to book ahead. This isn't a 'let's wander around Covent Garden and see what we find' kind of place, but once you're in, you'll be glad you did. The service is very American, which is lovely and refreshing at times, it's nice to be a bit catered to by an army of staff. The decor, like everyone has noted, is a replica of the NY one with loads of French charm. We did a brunch and aside from one of the best bloody marys I've had, the food was pretty epic. An eggs benedict that will not leave you feeling peckish afterwards.. oysters, baked mac & cheese, soufflé... you can easily go overboard with the decadence meter but you'll have to do it sometime, no?There's a bakery attached where you can take away some of the tempting sweets and fresh breads. It's a must stop for anyone that loves eating, you'll agonize over what to order and end up getting the entire menu like we did. It's not totally overpriced either, for what you get it's actually quite reasonable.

oo0WrwTdI_-HtmPtbIjWZQ.text: Wow. What lovely bread. The new salad of beets and carrots with burnt orange dressing  is just out if this world. The steak au poivre was just perfect and the service top notch.  I'm coming back.
